You'll notice I made a distinction between "theory" and "hypothesis".
A "theory", in scientific terms, is not defined in layman's terms. Meaning, "theory" doesn't simply mean "an idea". Scientifically, a "theory" is an idea which has an incredible amount of backing evidence from multiple sources. On the other hand, "hypothesis" simply means "an idea". Get it?
As for evolution and the age of the Earth, no, they are not "wrong". Evolution is established, as is the age of the Earth.

We have much evidence for the Big Bang. From physics to cosmology. Red shift, everything slowly (but surely) moving away from everything else, an invisible force called "dark matter" that is unseen but detectable as the remains of a vast expansion...it's all there.
So, yes, we can prove that. That's why it's a standing scientific theory and not simply a "hypothesis".
Extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence. When it comes to God, we have no evidence at all, let alone "extraordinary".

They can never prove the existence of the Higgs particle. They can only in numerous attempts test a theory. If what the Higgs particle is expected to do actually happens enough times, it starts to look as though they can't disprove the fact that it does not exist. And for each time they fail to disprove it's existence, it's existence becomes more likely. Hence, science is about disproving, not proving - at least, I guess that's what the guy meant.

That's basically what they were doing. They ran the experiment so many times that it's next to statistically impossible that the results they got were due to chance (i.e. that the hypothesis was wrong). So they tried, and failed, to disprove its existence.
